title: Luxurious Tomato Products To Keep Tomato Season Going Strong
description: Tomato season is peaking and fleeting, but you can keep it going with select luxury skincare, homewares, and accessories.
content:
It’s been two years since the concept of a tomato girl summer debuted, and the tomato girls are still very much loving it. Now in its third iteration, tomato girl summer seems stronger than ever, with tomato-scented, tomato-flavored, tomat0-shaped, and tomato-adorned, well, everything seeping into the mainstream. As tomatoes reach their peak at the farmer’s market and home gardens, sauce season looms, and tomato girl summer 3.0 will soon be a memory. Stock up on these tomato-themed products to keep tomato season going long after August.

New this summer, luxury beauty brand Lilfox’s “enzyme cleansing cocktail” bottles tomato seed and buah merah oils in Egyptian violet glass to preserve the botanical potency of this creamy cleanser. Made with the brand’s proprietary L-Beauty Ferment, plus papaya and pineapple enzymes, the organic product exudes vine-ripe tomato freshness. $95 for 100ml, lilfox.miami

Tomato scented candles are trending, but these taper candles take the concept to the next level with 100% vegetable wax candles that exude a fresh scent. The reddish pink hue is elegant in candelabras or just a baguette-turned candle stand. $44 for six, carrierefreres.com

Infuse any room, any time with the scent of fresh tomato thanks to this little bottle designed to neutralize odors for hours. The fragrance emulates a late summer, garden fresh tomato, plus some citrus and woodsy notes to really elevate the tomato-ness. $52 for 5 oz, malinandgoetz.com

Keep a delicate tomato detail enclosed in glass with this Italian oil bottle perfect for olive oil or vinegar. Designed in Italy by Ichendorf Milano this Borosilicate glass is 16 centimeters tall, 7 centimeters wide and can be a great gift with some tomato leaf or basil infused oil. $60, bignight.com

If tiny tomatoes are your thing, this summery red and white 100% cotton dress printed with on the vine tomatoes is for you! New to Rachel Antonoff’s summer collection, the button up casual piece can easily go from farmers market shopping to a tomato-fueled dinner. $258, anthropologie.com

Flamingo Estate is known for their slew of high-end tomato scented products, and the body lotion is among the best. Jojoba and avocado oils help hydrate skin, and the scent offers plenty of fresh tomato leaf with a bit of tarragon and black pepper for spice. $63 for 16 oz, flamingoestate.com

Embrace another tomato scent with Fully’s green tomato collection. This vegan night lotion uses 65% green tomato extract to help tighten pores, smoothe, and quench skin. $31 for 90 ml, thefullyglobal.com

You may not have a tomato plant growing inside, but your home can at least smell like a thriving tomato garden. Jo Malone’s green tomato vine diffuser offers a greenhouse-fresh scent, designed to last for months as its distributed among chic black reeds.
summary: The concept of a tomato girl summer, or "tomatic girl summer," has been gaining popularity with products like tomato-scented, tomato-flavored, tomat0-shaped, and tomato-adorned products. This summer, luxury beauty brand Lilfox's "enzyme cleansing cocktail" bottles tomato seed and buah merah oils in Egyptian violet glass to preserve the botanical potency of this creamy cleanser. Other products include 100% vegetable wax candles that exude a fresh scent, and Italian oil bottles designed to enclose a delicate tomato detail enclosed in glass with an Italian oil bottle designed for olive oil or vinegar. The fragrance of these products can enhance any room, any time with the scent of fresh tomato, and a vegan night lotion uses 65% green tomato extract to help tighten pores, smoothe, and quench skin.
shortSummary: Luxury products like Lilfox's "enzyme cleansing cocktail" and Jo Malone's green tomato diffuser, along with other tomato-themed products, ensure tomato girl summer 3.0 is here to stay.

Type "Tomato Girl Summer" into TikTok and you'll find a string of aesthetically pleasing shots of a certain type of travel lifestyle taking place right now—it involves farmers' markets, slow cooking in rustic kitchens, home-grown fruit and vegetables. Ideally, it has the Mediterranean as a backdrop but it can take place anywhere in the world—it just channels the ideals of this type of travel.
If you haven't seen it, maybe you're not part of this population cohort, one that uses TikTok. However, it's big news right now, fuelling travel obsessions. Vogue just wrote about it ("Before There Was Tomato Girl, There Were Tomatoes on the Runways") defining it as "Mediterranean-vacation-ready" looks and Slate defined what it takes to be a tomato girl, namely that it can't be exactly defined. More that it's someone living their best tomato-girl life, "posting dreamy vacation snaps from the Amalfi coast, wearing lots of linen, and drinking endless Aperol spritzes".
There are lots of videos of tomato girls currently on TikTok and beyond, with the trend taking hold in New York and featuring on Good Morning America. Tomato girl doesn't have to actually be wearing a red dress but it helps the aesthetic. Recent summer snaps of JLo and Billie Eilish are the inspiration for many tomato girls. Tomato girls don't have to be somewhere synonymous with fresh tomatoes—think the French Riviera or the Greek or Spanish islands—but they just have to be somewhere where they can post themselves lounging, cooking, drinking cocktails and looking great. The trend has even added Cucumber Girls into the mix.
It's not a new trend; it's just been given a new name for a younger generation. It is harmonious with the idea of slow travel, a certain type of Provençal lifestyle—the kind where everyone has the time to grow their own vegetables and still get dressed up for lunch and dinner to show off their chilled rosé wine by an (immaculate-looking) pool. As Slate says, it's "a way of performing a sort of effortless-looking elegance without being a member of the leisure class. In short, it’s a lovely illusion."
This is a trend that went viral when Instagram began, with the up-and-coming influencers of the early twenty-tens in Byron Bay, reviewed in Vanity Fair in 2019—Instagrammers that sell a version of surfing, entrepreneurial, youthful moms, hanging out together and making a living, selling perfect lifestyles, in one of the most picturesque parts of Australia.
TikTok is allowing people to take the out-of-office vibe, this travel ideal, and repackage it with videos, in memes, with teens or twenty-somethings re-selling it for their own demographic. And why not? Whilst it still might be selling an unattainable ideal—it's a hard lifestyle to maintain financially, not to mention the effort involved in always looking so Provençal-travel-ready, plus it's really hard work to actually grow all your own food—it is a trend that looks to a simpler life, a slower and a more fulfilling way to spend your time. Pretty much your average holiday ideal then.

argos_summary: The article explores the growing "tomato girl summer" trend, a TikTok‑driven aesthetic that celebrates Mediterranean‑style travel, slow living, and tomato‑themed fashion and home décor. It highlights a range of tomato‑infused products—from luxury beauty cleansers and scented candles to home sprays and clothing—showing how the trend permeates everyday life. The piece also traces the trend’s origins on Instagram and its evolution into a broader cultural phenomenon that blends aspirational travel with a simpler, garden‑centric lifestyle.
